author.value: Collection processed by Ted Casselman and Jane Latour.

corpname.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

unittitle.value: Teamsters for a Democratic Union, New York - New Jersey Chapter Records

extent.value: in 10 record cartons and 1 manuscript box.

abstract.value: Teamsters for a Democratic Union was formed in the 1970s by rank-and-file members of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters to combat corruption in their union.  The New York - New Jersey regional office of the TDU was established in 1987.  Materials include administrative records of the TDU, materials related to the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, records pertaining to Teamsters locals, records related to divisions within the union, individual grievances, legal records, correspondence, resource materials, and photographs.

p.value: Published citations should take the following form: <lb/><lb/>Identification of item, date; Teamsters for a Democratic Union, New York - New Jersey Chapter Records; WAG 136; box number; folder number; <lb/>Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives <lb/>Elmer Holmes Bobst Library <lb/>70 Washington Square South <lb/>New York, NY 10012, New York University Libraries.
Donated by the Teamsters for a Democratic Union, New York - New Jersey Chapter in 1998 and 2003. The accession numbers associated with this gift are 2003.021 and 2003.022.
Zeller, Duke.  <emph render="italic">Devil's Pact: Inside the World of the Teamsters Union</emph>.  Secaucus: Carol Publishing, 1996.

The Teamsters for a Democratic Union, New York - New Jersey Chapter Records includes administrative records of the TDU, materials related to the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, records pertaining to Teamsters locals, records related to divisions within the union, individual grievances, legal records, correspondence, resource materials, and photographs.

subject.value: Labor unions -- Political activity -- United States.

Series I: Organizational Records, 1965-1994Scope and Content Note

Series I includes TDU materials, including convention materials, steering committee notes, agendas, financial reports and organizing materials, rank and file flyers and campaign materials.

Series II consists of IBT materials collected by TDU. This includes material on the International's by-laws and constitution; convention materials; contracts and supplemental agreements; pension materials; various government records required by the LMRDA and material published under the Ron Carey administration on women in the union.

Councils 16, 73, 17, 18, 64 (+Tax returns) 1982-1994147Manual-Women in the Union (Carey Adm.)undated148Series III: International Brotherhood of Teamsters Locals, 1961-1994Scope and Content Note

Series III is arranged by Local numbers; the material relate to specific campaigns undertaken in those locals. Some records relate to pension fund campaigns and the efforts of TDU staff, in particular Susan Jennik to secure pension benefits for members. Additional materials include election records, mediation and arbitration awards; NLRB cases and grievance files; and collective bargaining. The records of Local 560, with its history of corruption and lengthy government-imposed trusteeship are of particular interest.

The materials in Series IV are divided as follows: Carhaul, Freight, and the National Master Freight Agreement. These records include materials from companies such as Roadway and Consolidated Freightways, two examples of national freight companies strengthened and emboldened by de-regulation.

Anchor Motor Freight; Opinion; Appellants Brief1988412Series VI: Legal, 1977-1994Scope and Content Note

Series VI is organized by court cases, many involving pension and benefit funds. The records also include materials from the government's case against the international union, U.S. v. La Cosa Nostra. Individuals featured include Dellacroce and Salerno. Some material relates to Jackie Presser's role as a government informant (see "Identity of Informant known as "Alpro.") The records contain the settlement and documents pertaining to supervision of the first direct election in the union's history. Materials developed by the TDU in preparation for the election are included in this series.

Series VII consists of subject files related to the union and the industry, as well as generic materials on labor and the reform movement. Various rank-and-file groups are represented, including those in the Utility Workers, the CWA, (New Directions caucus) the UAW, postal employees, etc.

Series IX includes photographs, contact sheets, and negatives from the late 1970s through late 1980s. These images are mainly from the Detroit area and depict TDU leaders and activists and demonstrations.
